answer_variants.answer: It is the process where Angular checks if any variables in your code have changed and then updates the screen to show those changes.

Change detection is the mechanism that keeps the UI in sync with the model. Angular reviews all components in the tree to check if any bound properties have changed since the last check and updates the DOM accordingly.
A process of detecting changes in the data of a component and its children. It is triggered by events, timers, or XHR calls and is executed by the change detector assigned to each component.
Automated sync between component state and view; triggered by asynchronous events.
It's like a teacher walking around a classroom checking every student's work to see who has finished a task (changed data) so they can move on to the next one.
Mechanism for syncing component state with the view.

Angular creates a directed graph of change detectors starting from the root. It uses Zone.js to monkey-patch asynchronous APIs, allowing the framework to know when a potential state change has occurred and start a re-render cycle.
Think of it as a constant supervisor that re-draws the screen whenever you click a button or type something.

Angular's change detection is unidirectional and top-down. By default, it uses the 'CheckAlways' strategy, but performance can be optimized using 'OnPush', which limits checks to immutable input changes or manual triggers.
The mechanism by which Angular synchronizes the state of the application UI with the state of the application data.
It is a library that helps Angular know when something asynchronous (like a timeout or click) happens so it can refresh the UI.

Zone.js is an execution context that persists across async tasks. It 'monkey-patches' common browser APIs (like setTimeout, Promise) to intercept their completion and notify Angular to run its change detection.
A library that creates a 'zone' of execution. Angular uses it to track asynchronous operations and trigger tick() at the end of the Microtask queue to perform change detection.
Library for tracking asynchronous tasks; enables automatic UI updates in Angular.

Zone.js is like a personal assistant who watches over everything you do. Every time you finish a side-task (like making a call or sending an email), they nudge your manager (Angular) to check if anything needs to be updated.
A library for intercepted async operations to notify Angular's Change Detection.
By wrapping low-level browser events in 'NgZone', Angular detects when a task starts and stops. This eliminated the need for manual 'apply()' or 'digest()' calls that were common in AngularJS.
It's a behind-the-scenes traffic controller that tells Angular: 'Hey, something just happened, you might want to update the screen now!'

While powerful, Zone.js can be a performance bottleneck or 'black box' for debugging. Modern Angular is moving toward 'Zoneless' apps using Signals, where state changes are tracked explicitly without monkey-patching.
An execution context that survives multiple asynchronous operations.
AOT compiles your app once before it goes to the browser. JIT compiles it every time it loads in the browser.

JIT compiles the application at runtime in the browser. AOT compiles it during the build process on your computer. AOT is the production standard because it results in smaller bundles and faster startup times.
JIT: Compilation happens on the client via the browser's JS engine. AOT: Angular templates and components are pre-compiled into JS by the Angular compiler (ngc) before deployment.
AOT: Pre-compilation (faster, smaller). JIT: Dynamic compilation (slower, requires compiler in bundle).
JIT is like ordering a meal where the chef starts cooking only after you arrive. AOT is like a buffet where the food is ready when you walk in—it's much faster for you to start eating.
Build-time compilation (AOT) vs Runtime compilation (JIT).
AOT offers better security as it catches template errors during the build and eliminates the need to ship the heavy Angular compiler (approx 1MB) with your production code.
AOT converts everything into a language the browser understands before you upload it, making the website load way quicker.
AOT enables Tree Shaking (removing unused code) and allows for smaller, more optimized code since the compiler doesn't need to resolve dynamic bindings at runtime.
Classification of Angular's two main compilation strategies for transforming templates into JavaScript.
DI is a way to provide a component with the services or data it needs without the component having to create them itself.

DI is a design pattern used to decouple components from their dependencies. Instead of creating instances of services manually, the component declares them in its constructor, and Angular's Injector provides them.
A hierarchical injection system that provides singleton or transient service instances to components. It uses an Injector to look up or create the requested dependency based on a provided token.
Design pattern where an object receives its dependencies from an external source (the Injector).
Think of a restaurant. A chef doesn't go to the farm to get eggs; they just ask the supplier to deliver them. The chef (component) just needs the eggs (service) to do their job.
A system where Angular provides objects needed by a class.
Angular's DI is hierarchical, meaning a component can receive a service instance from its own injector, a parent's, or the root. This allows for flexible service sharing and scope control.
It's like a delivery service for your code—it brings exactly what your component needs right when it starts.
Angular's DI uses a reflection-based mechanism (previously via reflect-metadata) to resolve constructor types, which is now heavily optimized by the Ivy compiler for better runtime efficiency.
A coding pattern in which a class asks for dependencies from external sources rather than creating them.
Ivy is the name of Angular's modern compiler and rendering engine that makes apps faster and smaller.

Ivy is the latest rendering engine for Angular (enabled by default since version 9). It significantly improves bundle size (via better tree shaking) and build times, and enables features like faster testing and better debugging.
An incremental DOM rendering architecture that uses a 'locality' principle—compilation of one component doesn't require knowledge of its parent or children, enabling faster rebuilds.
Angular's third-generation rendering engine; focuses on smaller bundles and faster compilation.

Ivy is like upgrading a car's engine from a heavy, old V8 to a modern, high-tech electric motor. The car looks the same from the outside, but it's much lighter, faster, and more efficient under the hood.
Angular's current high-performance rendering and compilation engine.

Prior to Ivy, Angular generated large factories for every component. Ivy produces 'template instructions' which are far more amenable to tree-shaking, meaning unused features in Angular's code don't end up in your production bundle.
It's the brain of Angular that was redesigned to make your website load instantly on phones.

Ivy leverages 'High-Level Instructions' (incrementally rendered DOM) which enables features like Higher Order Components and localized change detection, laying the groundwork for future 'Zoneless' apps.
The next-generation compilation and rendering pipeline for the Angular framework.
Bootstrapping is the process of starting your Angular application when the page loads.
Bootstrapping is the entry point of an Angular app. It's where you tell the framework which module (or component in standalone apps) to load first so it can begin rendering the UI.
The process of initializing an Angular application. Typically, it involves calling platformBrowserDynamic().bootstrapModule(AppModule) in main.ts.
Launching the application; defined in 'main.ts' via 'bootstrapModule' or 'bootstrapApplication'.
It's like turning the key in a car. It kicks off the ignition process that gets all the parts (components and services) moving together so you can drive (interact with the app).
The initialization process of an Angular application at startup.
During bootstrap, Angular creates the root module's injector, resolves the main component, and inserts it into the host element (usually <app-root>) found in index.html.
It's basically the 'Start' button that triggers everything else in your app to come alive.
In modern 'Standalone' Angular, bootstrapping is done via 'bootstrapApplication()', which allows for a more streamlined startup without the overhead of an explicit NgModule.
An initialization process that initializes the first Angular module or component of an application.
It means Angular has several layers of injectors that can provide different versions of a service depending on where you are in the app.

Angular's DI system is hierarchical. If a component asks for a dependency, Angular first looks at the component's own injector, then its parent's, all the way up to the root. This allows for creating multiple instances of a service at different levels.
A tree of injectors that mirrors the component tree. It provides a shadowing mechanism where child injectors can override providers from parent injectors.
Tree-structured dependency resolution system; allows for service overriding.
It's like a chain of command in a company. If you need a pencil, you ask your desk partner. If they don't have one, you ask your manager. If they don't have one, you go to the supply room (the root).
A tree-structured dependency resolution system mirroring the component tree.
There are two main hierarchies: the 'Module Injector' hierarchy (root, platforms) and the 'Element Injector' hierarchy (components/directives). The Element injector is checked first.
It's a way for Angular to find the right 'helper' for a component by looking at nearby components first before checking the whole house.

Hierarchical injection enables features like 'State per Component', where each instance of a reusable component can have its own private state service while still sharing a global configuration service from the root.
A system where providers are registered at different levels of the component and module tree.

questions.question: What is 'Polyfill' in an Angular project?

answer_variants.answer: It's code that adds missing features to older browsers so they can run modern Angular apps.
Polyfills are scripts that provide modern functionality on older browsers that do not natively support it. For Angular, it's essential for providing things like ES6 support and Zone.js functionality.
A piece of code (usually JavaScript) used to provide modern functionalities on older browsers that do not natively support it. It 'fills in' the holes in the browser's implementation.
Fallback code for browser compatibility; typically found in polyfills.ts.
Polyfills are like a translator. If you have a person who only speaks old Latin (an old browser) and you want to tell them a modern joke, the polyfill translates the new concepts so they understand.
Browser-compatibility code that fills gaps in missing features.

Since Angular uses advanced ES2015+ features, polyfills like 'core-js' and 'zone.js' are required to ensure the framework's internal mechanisms work in environments like Older Safari or Internet Explorer.
It's like an 'adapter' for your code that makes it work on older computers.
Modern Angular CLI optimizes polyfills using differential loading, serving different bundles to modern and legacy browsers to keep download sizes as small as possible.
JavaScript code that implements functions that a web browser is expected to provide natively.
It's a way to run code without triggering Angular's change detection, which is great for things that happen very often (like mouse moves).

This method allows you to run a block of code outside the Angular zone. This prevents Angular from automatically triggering change detection for every event in that block, which can significantly improve performance for high-frequency tasks.
An optimization to avoid unnecessary change detection cycles. It prevents the Task/Microtask hooks of Zone.js from notifying Angular, saving CPU cycles on intensive operations.
Optimization technique for executing code without triggering change detection; improves performance for constant async events.
It's like telling your over-eager personal assistant to 'go take a break' while you do some quick, unimportant paperwork so they don't keep bothering your boss with tiny updates.
Running code without triggering Angular's change detection process.

If you are running a library like D3 or Matter.js that has its own animation loop, running it inside the Angular zone would trigger thousands of change detection checks per second. running it 'outside' prevents this.
It's like a 'silent mode' for your code so it doesn't wake up the rest of the application every time it does something.
After finishing work outside the zone, you can use 'ngZone.run()' to step back into the zone and trigger a single UI update when the heavy work is complete.
A service method that allows execution of tasks outside the Angular execution context.
It is a rendering style used by Ivy that updates the screen by only changing the parts that actually need updating, saving memory.

Unlike Virtual DOM (used by React), Incremental DOM doesn't create intermediate snapshots of components. It generates template instructions that directly update the DOM in place. This makes it more memory efficient.

A technique where every component is compiled into a series of instructions. These instructions update the DOM directly without requiring a Virtual DOM representation, drastically reducing GC pressure.
Rendering architecture that updates the DOM directly via compiled instructions; key part of Ivy engine.

Virtual DOM is like taking a photo, comparing it to an old photo, and finding differences. Incremental DOM is like having a list of exactly which pixels to repaint on the screen without taking a photo at all.
A rendering technique that patches the DOM directly through instructions.
Incremental DOM significantly reduces memory usage as it doesn't need to store a second copy of the entire DOM in memory. This is especially beneficial for mobile devices with limited RAM.
It's a smarter way Angular handles visual updates so it doesn't have to 're-think' the whole page every time.
The primary advantage of Incremental DOM in Ivy is that the generated code is 'tree-shakeable'; if you don't use 'ngIf', the compiler won't even include the instruction code for it in the final JS.
A method of DOM reconciliation that updates the existing DOM elements directly.
